questions.question_text: A client has requested that the penetration test scan include the following UDP services: SNMP, NetBIOS, and DNS. Which of the following Nmap commands will perform the scan?

discussion.content:
This should be C.
With ICMP packets, all ICMP-based attacks cannot happen, smurf attacks included.
But since fraggle attacks exploit the UDP protocol and NOT ICMP, they stand are chance of being effective in this scenario
Ref: https://www.okta.com/identity-101/fraggle-attack/

Selected Answer: C
Option a. Fraggle is a similar type of attack that targets UDP (User Datagram Protocol) instead of ICMP. It involves sending a large number of spoofed UDP echo packets to network broadcast addresses, leading to amplification and flooding of the victim's IP address.

Selected Answer: C
A Fraggle Attack is a denial-of-service (DoS) attack that involves sending a large amount of spoofed UDP traffic to a router’s broadcast address within a network. It is very similar to a Smurf Attack, which uses spoofed ICMP traffic rather than UDP traffic to achieve the same goal. Given those routers (as of 1999) no longer forward packets directed at their broadcast addresses, most networks are now immune to Fraggle (and Smurf) attacks.

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is c

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C
Fraggle attack is same as a Smurf attack but rather than ICMP, UDP protocol is used. The prevention of these attacks is almost identical to Fraggle attack.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester who is conducting a vulnerability assessment discovers that ICMP is disabled on a network segment. Which of the following could be used for a denial-of-service attack on the network segment?

choices.D: The rules of engagement from the assessment
choices.C: The executive summary and information regarding the testing company
choices.B: Information regarding the business impact if compromised
choices.A: A quick description of the vulnerability and a high-level control to fix it

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of information should be included when writing the remediation section of a penetration test report to be viewed by the systems administrator and technical staff?

discussion.content:
I think A is the best answer given the audience.
The systems administrator and the technical stuff would be more interested in the technical aspect of the findings
A - seems to be the correct one

100% A - based on the audience, technical info would be relevant.

Which of the following edits should the tester make to the script to determine the user context in which the server is being run?
